column1: The Doshisha Corporation (English: The Doshisha) is the educational corporation to which Doshisha University and Doshisha Women's College belong.

Doshisha was founded in 1875 by Joseph Hardy Neesima as a Christian Protestant (Congregational) school, and is a comprehensive educational institution with nine educational facilities bearing the name "Doshisha" from university to kindergarten (as of April 2005).
As of April 2004, approximately 36,000 people are studying at Doshisha University.
Currently, Doshisha School Corporation has obtained <AA+> from Rating and Investment Information, Inc. (R&I).
<AA+> is the second highest rating out of 21 levels.
Alongside Waseda University and Keio University, it is the top school corporation.
The founding spirit of Doshisha University is "conscience" based on Christian spirit.
Shinshiro Toshimasa aimed to cultivate individuals who could utilize their conscience in their actions as the purpose of education.
It is desired to produce people who are "filled with conscience" by promoting "character education" based on Christianity in parallel with knowledge education.
Monuments engraved with his handwriting expressing those thoughts can be found at various schools such as Doshisha University.
The words "May the spirit of righteousness fill the whole body and bring forth a strong will" are engraved on this monument of conscience.

Furthermore, in order to concretely realize this "education of conscience," the educational principles of "Christianity," "liberalism," and "internationalism" are advocated, aiming to produce individuals who embody the "conscience of a nation" through these principles.
It is a Protestant school corporation with roots in the Congregationalist tradition.

However, it is different in nature from so-called mission-based universities and does not have as its primary purpose the Christian mission (it does not use education itself as a means of evangelism).
A school corporation founded by one of the six great educators of the Meiji era in 1875, Shinshu Shimajima, which originated from Doshisha English School.
In 1875, J.C. Hepburn founded Doshisha English School in Marutamachi, Teramachi, Kyoto.
In 1876, it moved from Teramachi to Imadegawa.
In April 1877, the Doshisha branch school for women was established, and in September it was renamed Doshisha Women's School.
In 1883, the rules of Doshisha Society were established.
In 1888, the "Purpose of Establishing Doshisha University" was announced in major newspapers and magazines nationwide.
In 1896, the ordinary school was renamed Doshisha High School.
Established the Doshisha Junior High School.
In 1897, M.F. Denton opened the Demachi Kindergarten.
In 1900, Shutchou Kindergarten was renamed to Imadegawa Kindergarten.
In 1904, theological schools and vocational schools were established under the Vocational School Order.

In 1912, Doshisha University (preparatory school, theology department, faculty of political economy, English department) and Women's School Specialized Department (English department, home economics department) were established under the Vocational School Law.
Doshisha University was founded in 1920 under the University Ordinance.
Ikkyu Sojun was a Zen monk of the Rinzai sect of the Rinzai sect of the Muromachi period.
Known as a model of storytelling.

Regarding "Ikkyu-san no Tonchi-banashi," please refer to the section on "Ikkyu-banashi" (there is also some description on this page). For information on the TV anime "Ikkyu-san," please refer to the section on "Ikkyu-san."
Born in Kyoto, said to be a descendant of Emperor Go-Komatsu.

In the diary of Sugawara Nagamasa, "Diary of Tohbojo Nagamasa" in the third year of Meio (1494), it is written on the first day of August: "It is said in secret that Ikkyu Sojun is the illegitimate child of Emperor Gohanazono."
"There is no one in the world who knows it."
According to later historical records, his childhood name was Chigikumaru.
He was later called Zhou Jian, and went by the aliases of Kuang Yunzi, Xialu, and Mukei.
The posthumous Buddhist name is Shu Jun, also written as Shu Jun.
Ikkyu is a Buddhist monk's title.
Please refer to the "posthumous Buddhist name" section for information on posthumous Buddhist names and Buddhist titles.
At the age of 6, he entered the Ankokuzan Hōkō-ji in Kyoto and received the precepts, being named Shūken.

From an early age, he excelled in poetry, and his Chinese poems "Nagato Harugusa" composed at the age of 13 and "Spring Clothes Lodging Flowers" composed at the age of 15 became well-known and praised in the capital city of Kyoto.
In the 17th year of Oei (1410), at the age of 17, he became a disciple of Ken'o Soin and changed his Buddhist name to Soshun.
At this time, it cannot be determined whether Ikkyu's behavior is due to his master's passing, but he has attempted suicide.
In the 22nd year of the Ōei era (1415), he became a disciple of Kasō Sōdon, a high priest at Daitoku-ji Temple in Kyoto.

He received the title of Ikkyu from Kaso for his response to the koan "The Stick of Dongshan's Three Blows": "Returning from the non-being to the being, take a rest. When it rains, let it rain. When the wind blows, let it blow."
"Arroji (world of defilements)" refers to the world of delusion (afflictions), while "muroji (world of enlightenment)" refers to the world of enlightenment (Buddha).
One night in the 27th year of Oei (1420), upon hearing the cawing of a crow, I suddenly had a great realization.
The old man tried to give a letter of approval to Ikkyu, but he declined.
It is said that the old man sent him off laughing as a fool.
Afterwards, I lived a life of poetry, mad songs, calligraphy, and eccentricity.
In the first year of Shōchō (1428), Emperor Go-Komatsu passed away without leaving a male heir, and Emperor Go-Hanazono was welcomed from the Fushimi-no-miya family and ascended to the throne.
It is said that Ikkyu recommended the enthronement of Emperor Go-Hanazono.
From "The Biography of Ikkyu Sojun in the Tokai Region".
However, Imaizumi Yoshio argues that the enthronement of Go-Hanazono was approved by the shogunate and was not related to Ikkyu's recommendation.

In the 6th year of Bunmei after the Ōnin War (1474), he was appointed as the head priest of Daitoku-ji by the decree of Emperor Go-Tsuchimikado, the 47th head priest. He did not reside in the temple, but he worked hard for its revival.
The Kyoto Imperial Palace (Kyoto Gosho) is the imperial residence located in Kamigyo-ku, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Due to the Tokyo visit of the Meiji Restoration, the Emperor moved to the Imperial Palace in Tokyo (formerly Edo Castle), and it was preserved in the 10th year of Meiji (1877).
After the Meiji era, it was also known as the Kyoto Imperial Palace.
Originally, the official Imperial Palace in Heian-kyo was located in the central part of Heian-kyo, but it was moved to the Rikyu Palace due to damage caused by wars and other factors.
The Togu Palace of the Daitokuji Temple was one of the palaces in this village, where the imperial family of the Jomyo-in lineage, later known as the Northern Court, resided.
By the way, the imperial palace of the Daikakuji line, which is called the Southern Court, was located in Nijo Tomikoji Uchiraku.
The modern Kyoto Imperial Palace is not the same as the original Tsuchimikado Higashidono-in, but rather an expansion based on the Tsuchimikado Higashidono-in.
Usually, you can visit by applying, and it is open to the public in spring and autumn.
The Kyoto Imperial Palace was the residence and office of successive emperors until the Imperial Court moved to Tokyo in the second year of the Meiji era (1869).
The Kyoto Imperial Palace in the present day (21st century) is classified as "Imperial property" under the jurisdiction of the Imperial Household Agency.

Adjacent to Kyoto Imperial Palace and Sentō Imperial Palace, and across the street to the north on Imadegawa Street are Doshisha University and Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts (both campuses are located on Imadegawa Street).

Currently, the Imperial Household Agency manages the Kyoto Imperial Palace, Kyoto Imperial Palace, and Sento Imperial Palace, while the Ministry of the Environment manages the Kyoto Gyoen National Garden surrounding them.
Kyoto residents often simply refer to the Kyoto Imperial Palace as "Gosho," including the Kyoto Imperial Garden.

There is a theory that the walls surrounding the Imperial Palace are not very high compared to castles overseas, reflecting the difference in the sense of closeness between the common people and rulers (such as the Emperor and other imperial family members) in the East and West.

For example, during the French Revolution, there was an incident where commoners invaded the Palace of Versailles, which was the residence of the ruler (king). This is one of the reasons why such incidents have not occurred in Japan.

The original Imperial Palace of Heian-kyo was located considerably to the west of the current Kyoto Imperial Palace, near the JR Nijo Station in Kyoto, at the northeast corner of the Senbon Marutamachi intersection.

The current Kyoto Imperial Palace was originally one of the residences of the retired Emperor, called the Tsuchimikado Higashidono, and was first used by Emperor Kogon of the Northern Court in the first year of the Genko era (1331).

The Imperial Palace that was once located here was rebuilt eight times during the Edo period (six of which were due to fires), and the existing building was reconstructed in the late Edo period in the second year of Ansei (1855) in the Heian style, known as the Ansei Imperial Palace.

In the 10th year of Meiji (1877), Emperor Meiji, who had moved to the Imperial Palace in Tokyo, visited Kyoto and lamented the deteriorating state of the Kyoto Imperial Palace, which had fallen into disrepair within 10 years of his visit to Tokyo. He ordered for the preservation of the palace and the maintenance of its former appearance.
Main buildings include the Shishin-den, Seiryo-den, Kogosho, Ogakumonjo, Tsunegoten, Koushun, Osuzumisho, and the Empress's Palace.

The enthronement ceremony has been traditionally held at the Shishin-den Hall in the Kyoto Imperial Palace for generations. Even after the Emperor moved to Tokyo during the Meiji Restoration, according to the Imperial Household Law established in 1889 (Meiji 22), it was stipulated that the enthronement ceremony and the Daijosai ceremony should be held in Kyoto. Both Emperor Taisho and Emperor Showa also performed their enthronement ceremonies at the Kyoto Imperial Palace.

Furthermore, there is no specific provision in the current Imperial Household Law established after World War II that the enthronement ceremony must be held in Kyoto. In 1990, for the enthronement of the current Emperor, for the first time in history, the enthronement ceremony was held at the Imperial Palace in Tokyo.

During the enthronement ceremony, the Emperor sits on the Takamikura, the official throne of the Emperor symbolizing the enthronement, which is located in the Shishin-den Hall of the Kyoto Imperial Palace. Therefore, for the current Emperor's enthronement ceremony "Sokuirei-Seiden-no-Gi" (equivalent to "Shishin-den-no-Gi"), the Takamikura was temporarily moved to the Imperial Palace.

Gagaku is one of the traditional music of Japan, China, the Korean Peninsula, and Vietnam.
The following will focus on Japanese gagaku transmitted to the Imperial Household Agency Shikibu Department Music Department (Important Intangible Cultural Property).
The original meaning of gagaku is "elegant and correct music and dance," contrasting with "popular music."

According to the definition by the Imperial Household Agency Shikibu-shoku Gakubu, it refers to the repertoire performed by the Imperial Household Agency Shikibu-shoku Gakubu, excluding Western music.
Many of them have been inherited as court music in instrumental music.
It is the oldest style of traditional music in the world that is still performed in large ensemble form today.

However, as a form of ensemble music, Gagaku had been discontinued for over 100 years since the Onin War until the Tokugawa shogunate gathered the descendants of musicians (Gagakuka) and reorganized it, so it is questionable how much of the Heian period form has been inherited.

When singing the musical notation written in katakana for the biwa, it is speculated that the pronunciation of Japanese from before the 16th century is faithfully reproduced, such as pronouncing the "ha" sound as "fa, fi, fu, fe, fo," when adding rhythm to the musical characters to sing as a chant melody.

Things written in kanji, like the notation for the raku biwa, share many similarities with the biwa scores discovered in Dunhuang, China, and further inherit many styles that were passed down from an even older continent.
One of the most important historical sources is the "Taigen Shō" written by Toyohara Tsunemasa (1450-1512), who was concerned about the dispersal of records such as gagaku due to the Ōnin War.
Tsuneaki, the head of the Shakuhachi family, compiled records about Gagaku and Bugaku centered around the shakuhachi, making it a valuable record of ancient Gagaku.
The music for rituals that was transmitted from China, the Korean Peninsula, and South Asia before the 10th century is the basis.
In China, ya-yüe was music performed at ceremonies.

However, among the pieces currently performed in Japanese gagaku, Tang music, which is said to have been transmitted from China, is said to be based on the music played at a banquet called Yan music in the Tang dynasty.

In terms of music categories, there are various international names such as Tang music, Goryeo music, and Linyi music (music of Champa), reflecting the diverse cultural influences. Additionally, elements of ancient Japanese music from before the introduction of continental music are also included.

Before modern times, the Tennoji Gakuso of Shitennoji Temple (Osaka), the Dainai Gakuso of the Imperial Palace (Kyoto), and the Nanto Gakuso of Kasuga Grand Shrine (Nara) were considered the three major Gakuso.

These music schools were called to Tokyo in modern times, forming the foundation of the current Imperial Household Agency's music department, but the traditions of each music school continue in their respective regions.
In addition, mutual influences can be seen between folk songs and statements, and Japan's unique style has been created.
Currently, about 100 songs have been inherited by the Imperial Household Agency's Music Department.

Emperor Kanmu (737-806) was the 50th Emperor of Japan.
Emperor Kanmu was born as the first son of Prince Shirabe (later Emperor Kōnin) in the 9th year of Tenpyō (737).
According to the Nihon Shoki, Takano Shin no Kasuga, the mother, is said to be a descendant of the Baekje royal family, with King Munju of Baekje as her ancestor.
Empress Fujiwara no Otomuro gave birth to Prince Yasumaro (later Emperor Heijō), and Empress Fujiwara no Tabiko gave birth to Prince Ōtomo (later Emperor Junna).

Even after his father, the White Wall King, ascended to the throne, Prince Shotoku was not desired to be the crown prince because his mother, Kōno Shōkatsu, belonged to the low-ranking immigrant clan of the Wa clan. Initially, he aimed for career advancement as a bureaucrat, serving as a chamberlain, head of the university, and minister of the center.

However, due to political disputes involving the Fujiwara clan, the former Crown Prince and his mother, Empress Inoue, were suddenly deposed and the younger half-brother was made Crown Prince on January 2, 773, in the 4th year of the Hoki era.
The influence of the various Nara Buddhist temples in Heijokyo had grown too large, so the capital was moved to Yamashiro Province.
In 784, Nagaoka-kyo was built, but in 794, Heian-kyo was built again.
In order to invade the Tohoku region and subjugate the Emishi, a military force was sent with Sakanoue no Tamuramaro as the commander-in-chief.
However, in his later years, he was criticized by Fujiwara no Yoshitsugu of the Fujiwara Shikike family for causing suffering to the peasants with such military and construction projects.
It is said that he proposed the compilation of the Nihon Shoki in terms of culture.
Saicho and Kukai returned from Tang China and brought new developments to Japanese Buddhism under the reign of Emperor Kanmu.

The unnatural deaths of Princess Inoue and Prince Tachibana, as well as the dark side of the beginning of his reign, included the assassination of Prince Hayara by Fujiwara Tanezaki in 785, who was then exiled and died in confinement.

Out of fear of vengeful spirits, on July 19, 800 AD, Emperor Kanmu posthumously honored Prince Sawara as Emperor Sudo, designated Princess Inoue's tomb as a mausoleum, and restored the position of Empress.

Known as the protectors of Saicho and Kukai, on the other hand, existing Buddhism has been too involved in politics and has exerted too much power, so they have put pressure on various sects known as the "Nanto Rokushu" by confiscating their land.
It is also said that the disorder in the imperial harem led to the later "Incident at Yaxie".
He passed away on March 17, 806, in the 25th year of the Enryaku era.
Emperor Jimmu, who was posthumously known as Yamato Takeru Ihare no Mikoto, was enthroned in Japan.
Along with this, Emperor Kanmu was posthumously given the Chinese-style posthumous title.
Kashiwabara Emperor, also known as Tenkoku Oshihara Miya Kashiwabara Tenno.
The tomb is said to be the Kashiwabara Mausoleum in Momoyama-cho, Fushimi-ku, Kyoto City.
Before his death, he was insistent on being buried in Utono, but due to various reasons, he was buried in Fushimi's Kashiwabara Mausoleum.
In the Meiji era, the first emperor of Heian-kyo was enshrined at Heian Shrine.
All emperors are enshrined in one of the three Imperial Mausoleums at the Imperial Palace.

On December 18, 2001, before the Emperor's birthday, which has become a tradition, Akihito made a statement during a press conference regarding the co-hosting of the FIFA World Cup the following year, saying, "I feel a connection with the Republic of Korea as it is recorded in the Nihon Shoki that the mother of Emperor Kanmu was a descendant of King Munmu of Baekje."
This statement was not widely covered in Japan, but it was widely reported in the South Korean media and became a topic of discussion.
Some media outlets have made a big leap in logic, claiming that the Imperial Family has Korean ancestry, based on theories such as the "Imperial Family Baekje Origin Theory."
The Otani family (Ootanike) is the family name of the descendants of Kakuei, the son of Kakushin-ni and Hino Hirotuna.

Hino Hirotsuna was a lower-ranking noble in Kyoto, while Kakushin-ni was the daughter of Shinran who inherited the position of head priest (hōshu) of the Jōdo Shinshū sect's main temple, Higashi Hongan-ji.

When surnames became mandatory during the Meiji era, both the head priests of the Jodo Shinshu Honganji sect (Nishi Honganji) and the head priests of the Shinshu Otani sect (Shinshu Honbyo) that split in 1602 took on surnames.
The origin of the Otani surname is due to the fact that the mausoleum of Shinran, mentioned later, was established in the Otani area north of the Chion-in Temple's gate in Higashiyama, Kyoto.

Hongan-ji was considered one of the daimyo (feudal lords) during the Sengoku period in Japan, as it had power comparable to that of the daimyo due to the spread of the Ikko Ikki movement. It is common to refer to the head priest with the temple's name attached, such as "Hongan-ji Kennyo" or "Hongan-ji Kosa," but this is purely for convenience and does not mean that the head priest's family lineage made Hongan-ji their surname, nor that there was a Hongan-ji clan.
Kakushin-ni watched over Shinran as he passed away in 1262, and in 1272 she built a hall in Otani near their home in Higashiyama, Kyoto to enshrine his remains.

Daibutsu-do became a place of worship for Jodo Shinshu followers as the mausoleum of Shinran, attracting their reverence. Shinran's eldest son, Kakuei, was appointed as the caretaker of the temple in his absence.

However, the Otani mausoleum later became a source of conflict between the disciples of various provinces due to the gathering of pilgrimages and donations. This led to a dispute between Kakuei's son Kakunyo and Kakuei's half-brother Yosho over the position of head priest, with Kakunyo ultimately emerging victorious and establishing the hereditary succession of the position within his own family line.
In 1312, Kakunyo converted the mausoleum into a temple, giving birth to the Jodo Shinshu sect.

Since then, the descendants of Kakunyo inherited the Honganji Temple and advanced the formation of the sect. By the time of the 5th generation Jakkunyo in the Muromachi period, the Honganji Temple expanded to the Hokuriku region, and by the time of the 7th generation Sonnyo, the Honganji sect had been formed in Kaga, Noto, Echizen, Omi, and other provinces.

However, compared to other lineages of Jodo Shinshu that have been working on forming the sect since after Shinran's death, the formation of the sect was significantly delayed. In the early Muromachi period, Honganji was considered a sub-temple of Seiren-in, and it is said that the Otani family, through their connection to the Hino family (Shinran's birth family), also served as stewards for the Kujo family.

In the latter half of the 15th century, due to the activities of Rennyo, who became the 8th head priest, the Honganji sect spread throughout Japan. However, in 1465, the main Honganji temple was destroyed and the head priest moved to Yoshizaki in Echizen, and then to the Yamashina district on the outskirts of Kyoto.

In Kaga, against the backdrop of the expansion of the teachings during the time of Rennyo, the Kaga Ikko Ikki occurred in 1488, leading to the expulsion of the guardian Tomogashi family by the Honganji sect in Kaga, resulting in the emergence of a situation known as the "country ruled by peasants."
For approximately one hundred years until 1580, it became a country ruled by the Ikko sect.

In the 16th century, amidst the chaos of the Warring States period, the Honganji sect, starting from small farmers, strengthened its organizational power and expanded its activities throughout Japan, reaching the warrior class such as samurai and local lords. However, the Yamashina Honganji temple suffered from the Tenbun Hokke Disturbance in 1532, and the 10th head, Shonyo, relocated to the Ishiyama Gobo founded by Rennyo in Nishinaru-gun, Settsu Province (present-day Osaka City), establishing the Ishiyama Honganji temple.
Ishiyama Hongan-ji was located at the top of a hill at the northern end of the Kamimachi Plateau.
The key point of river transportation at the mouth of the Yodogawa River was dominated by Osaka.
Based in Ishiyama Hongan-ji, Shonin sought to strengthen ties with various daimyo, the shogunate, and the imperial court, stabilizing the power base of Hongan-ji.
On the other hand, from the end of the Jisho era, in regions such as Hokuriku, some members of the Honganji sect were beginning to deviate from the control of Honganji and follow their own path.

During the time of the 11th head priest Kennyo, the Honganji sect, which had effectively become an independent daimyo power, expanded into the Kinai region and came into conflict with Oda Nobunaga, who sought to establish unified control by taking away feudal lord power from religious forces.

The conflict between the Honganji Temple and the Oda clan, which lasted for ten years from 1570, known as the Ishiyama War, saw the fortified Honganji Temple in Ishiyama being defended by Kennyo and other monks, while Honganji followers across the country resisted the Oda clan. This alliance allowed the Honganji Temple to gain the upper hand and greatly trouble Nobunaga.

However, in 1574, Ganjoji Temple in Nagashima-cho, Ise Province (Mie Prefecture) was destroyed by the Oda clan, and in 1575, the Ikko Ikki that recaptured Echizen from the Oda clan was annihilated, weakening resistance in various regions. In 1578, the Mori clan's navy, allied with Honganji Temple, was defeated by the Oda navy in the Battle of Kizu River, marking a series of defeats for Honganji Temple outside its walls.

Despite continuing to gather support from the Iga clan and others, Ishiyama Hongan-ji maintained its strength. However, it gradually became isolated among its enemies, and in 1580, it finally succumbed to Nobunaga, who had obtained an imperial decree from Emperor Ogimachi, and retreated from Ishiyama Hongan-ji. The power of Ishiyama Hongan-ji as a feudal lord disappeared.

At this time, the eldest son Noriyoshi and Kenjo, who continued to resist against Kenjo's intentions, had a falling out. When Kenjo passed away in 1593, his third son Junjo was appointed as his successor.

From this point on, Hongan-ji began to walk the path of division over the position of the head priest, and in 1602 Tokugawa Ieyasu granted a separate temple ground to Kyonyo's Hongan-ji sect, led by Kyonyo, and established the East Hongan-ji.

At this time, many followers from the Jodo sect led by Junjo, who became the head of Nishi Honganji, moved to the guidance of Kyonyo, the head of Higashi Honganji, and Honganji split into two factions, east and west.

Shinran, originally the son of Hino Arinori, a court noble, and the head of the Eastern and Western Hino families, who descended from Hino Hirotane (the father of Kakunyo), had a tradition of becoming adopted sons of powerful court nobles for generations. They also continued to intermarry with court nobles for generations, leading to the advancement of their status through the maternal line.
Kyotanabe City is located near the border of Osaka Prefecture and Nara Prefecture in the southern part of Kyoto Prefecture.

Kyo-tanabe City is located in the central part of the triangular area of the three prefectures, adjacent to Yawata City, Joyo City, Ide Town in Tsuzuki District, Seika Town in Sagara District, Hirakata City in Osaka Prefecture, and Ikoma City in Nara Prefecture in the southern part of Kyoto Prefecture.

The Kizugawa River flows north-south along the eastern side of the city (Kyoto Prefecture), while the western side is sandwiched by the Ikoma Mountain Range, with the central area being crossed by the West Japan Railway Company's Karasuma Line and the Kintetsu Kyoto Line.
Kyoto City, Nara City, and Osaka City have a strong character as bedroom communities.

On the same day, the name change of "Kyoto Prefecture Tanabe City" to "Kyoto Prefecture Kyotanabe City" was also implemented.

Heian-kyo was established as the capital of Japan by Emperor Kammu in the year 794 (Enryaku 13).

Heian-kyo was built in the area that now corresponds to the central part of Kyoto City, spanning the Katsura District and the Atago District in Yamashiro Province. It was a capital city that was divided into a rectangular shape measuring 4.5km east to west and 5.2km north to south.

Establish the Imperial Palace at the northern center of the capital, and from there, create the Suzaku Avenue running through the center of the city, with the districts of Rakuchu (on the east side) and Ukyo (on the west side) on either side.
The layout plan is basically based on Heijokyo, following the example of Chang'an in the Sui and Tang dynasties.
However, there were no city walls.
There is a theory that the selection of this land was based on the Four Gods corresponding to Feng Shui, which was transmitted from China.
The area of Heian-kyo is smaller than the current Kyoto city.
The northernmost main road is Ichijo Street, located between Imadegawa Street and Marutamachi Street.

Emperor Kanmu moved the capital to Yamashiro Province in 784 and built Nagaoka-kyo.

It is said that there was an intention to move away from the powerful nobles and temples that supported the government of the Emperor Tenmu's lineage in Yamato Province, and to establish a new capital for the Emperor Tenchi's lineage.
However, just 10 years later in 794, Emperor Kammu relocated the capital to the northern part of Yamashiro Province, and Heian-kyo was established.

This relocation of the capital is believed to have been influenced by a series of incidents that led from the assassination of Fujiwara Tane-tsugu in Nagaoka-kyo to the removal of Prince Sawara, as well as the slow progress of the construction of Nagaoka-kyo.
It is believed that the construction of Heian-kyo began with the building of the Imperial Palace (Daijokyu) and then proceeded to the construction of the city (urban area).
However, due to the fact that the area of Ukyo is a wetland formed by the Katsura River (part of the Yodo River system), urbanization did not progress even into the 9th century.
In the 10th century, when the Ritsuryo system had largely become obsolete, there were cases of land being converted to agricultural use, which was originally prohibited within the capital.
The residential area for the nobility was established in the left capital, excluding the northern part of the right capital near the Daitokuji.
The Nihon Koki is an official history book compiled in the early Heian period, and is the third of the six national histories following the Nihon Shoki.
Completed in the 7th year of the Jōwa era (840), it covers a period of 42 years from the 11th year of the Enryaku era (792) to the 10th year of the Tenchō era (833).
The editor is Fujiwara no Tsugutsugu and others.
According to the preface, in the 10th year of Konin (819), Emperor Saga ordered Fujiwara no Fuyutsugu, Fujiwara no Otsugu, Fujiwara no Sadatsugu, and Yoshimine Yasuyo to compile the text.

Three people, excluding the unfinished successor, died, so Emperor Junna later ordered Kiyohara Natsuno, Prince Naoyuki, Fujiwara Yoshino, Ono Minomori, Sakagami Imotsugu, and Shimada Kiyota to continue.
During the reign of Emperor Nimmyo, further decrees were issued to Fujiwara no Otsugu, Minamoto Tsunemoto, Fujiwara Yoshino, Fujiwara Yoshifusa, and Asano Shikatori.
Furthermore, after adding Furutakaniwa and Yamada Furuetsugu, the completion was finally reported on December 9, 841 (January 5, 841) in the 7th year of the Jōwa era.
The period it took to compile was 21 years, and the only person who was involved in the project spanning three emperors was Fujiwara no Suketsugu.
Following the "Nihon Shoki," this text records the reigns of Emperor Heizei, Emperor Saga, and Emperor Junna during the reign of Emperor Kanmu.

In the early 15th century, there were 40 volumes of the text, but they were later scattered. It was not until the disciple of Hani Hoemiichi, Inayama Yukinori, discovered a manuscript of 10 volumes at the Sanjo Nishi family (there is also a theory of the edited version by Yanagihara Norimitsu) that it was first published.
The existing volumes are volumes 5, 8, 12, 13 (Kammu), 14, 17 (Heijou), 20, 21, 22, 24 (Saga), totaling 10 volumes, with the reign of Emperor Junna completely missing.

It is possible to partially reconstruct the text from the excerpt version of the six national histories such as "Nihonki Ryaku" and the classification of the six national histories in "Ruiju Kokushi".

There are "Nihon Isshi" and "Nihon Koki Ibun" which collect various excerpts from different places, based on which, the following Shueisha translated and annotated Japanese historical materials and Kodansha academic library have been published.
It is said that the content most reflects the opinion of Fujiwara no Noritoshi.

Adding short biographies (obituaries) to the death articles of the Emperor and court officials is in line with the "Continuation of Japanese Chronicles," and is the same as other subsequent historical books.

However, the obituary of this book does not flow into one-sided, official praise or criticism, but rather contains many interesting descriptions with unique criticisms and impressions, making it unique in the Six National Histories for maintaining a critical spirit.
It is known that the Rikkokushi contained a larger number of waka poems compared to earlier and later historical texts.
Sei Shonagon (around the third year of the Kocho era (966?) - around the second year of the Manju era (1025?)) was a female writer and poet of the Heian period.
There is a theory that her real name is Nagiko Kiyohara, but it is unknown.
One of the "Five Men of Pear Jar," she was the daughter of the renowned poet Kiyohara no Motosuke (908-990) in his later years.
There is an old tradition that identifies the mother as "Higaki no Ouna" in the "Gosen Wakashu," but this is nothing more than a wild and baseless theory.
My great-great-grandfather (some say great-grandfather) is the representative poet of the Kokin Wakashu, Kiyohara no Motosuke.
There are women who became the wives of Gagaku leader Narinari, Dazai Shokan, Kaisyu of Hanayama-in, and Fujiwara Norinou (the siblings of Fujiwara Michitsuna's mother).
"Sei Shonagon" is a pseudonym, with "Sei" taken from her family name Seiwa and "Shonagon" from a court title held by her relatives.
The real name is unknown, and there is a theory that it is "Nagiko" (from "Makura no Soshi Shou"), but it is not reliable.

She is counted as one of the thirty-six Immortal Poets of the Heian period, and her collection of 42 poems, "Kiyoshinagonshu" (the number of poems varies depending on the version, with 31 poems in some manuscripts), has been handed down.
In the "Goshūi Wakashū," 14 poems were selected for inclusion in the imperial anthology.
Ashikaga Yoshiteru was the 15th shogun of the Muromachi shogunate and the last shogun of the Muromachi shogunate (reign: Eiroku 11 (1568) - Tensho 16 (1588)).
The father is Ashikaga Yoshiharu, the 12th shogun of the Muromachi shogunate.
The mother is the daughter of Konoe Hisamichi, Keijuin.
The 13th shogun, Ashikaga Yoshiteru, is a half-brother.
At first, he was a monk, but when Yoshiteru was assassinated by Matsunaga Hisahide and others, he escaped from Kyoto with the help of Hosokawa Yusai and other vassals.
He was supported by Oda Nobunaga of Mino Province and went up to Kyoto, where he became the 15th shogun.
Eventually, he came into conflict with Nobunaga and, in conjunction with Takeda Shingen and Asakura Yoshikage, built a coalition to surround Nobunaga.
At one point, Nobunaga was cornered, but eventually he was expelled from Kyoto by Nobunaga, and the Muromachi shogunate was effectively destroyed.
After that, he spent his remaining years with the support of Motonari Mōri and then Toyotomi Hideyoshi.
He was born on November 13, 1537, as the second son of the 12th shogun, Ashikaga Yoshiharu.

Because there was a legitimate child of his older brother, Ashikaga Yoshiteru, he became an adopted child of his maternal grandfather, Konoe Hisatsugu, at a young age and entered the Buddhist priesthood (Kofukuji Ichijo-in) under the name Kakukei.
He later advanced to the position of Gonsyosu at Kofukuji Temple.

In the Eiroku Incident of Eiroku 8 (1565), the 13th shogun, my brother Yoshiteru, was assassinated by Matsunaga Hisahide and the Sanjo Sanekiyo, and my younger brother, Ashikaga Shuson, who was the head of the Kano-in Temple, was also lured to his death.

At this time, Yoshiaki was also captured by Matsunaga Hisahide and others, and imprisoned in Kofukuji Temple (Hisahide and others feared turning Kofukuji Temple into an enemy by killing Yoshiaki, as Yoshiaki was the younger brother of the shogun and had been promised the position of head priest of Kofukuji Temple in the future, so they decided to imprison him instead).

However, with the help of vassals such as Hosokawa Yusai and Wada Koremasa, he managed to escape and on February 17, 1566, in the 9th year of the Eiroku era, he returned to secular life and took the name Yoshiaki.
In the book that recorded the life of Yoshiaki, it is mentioned that he was also referred to as the "Warrior's Palace" and other aliases.
When he was expelled from Kyoto, he was attacked by night thieves and was also known as the "Poor Governor."
On April 21st, he was quietly promoted to Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade and appointed as Left Cavalry Captain.

There are opinions questioning the timing of the appointment, but according to Yamashina Genkitsu's "Genkitsu Kyo-ki", it is clear that he had already received the appointment before the day of the appointment of the shogun to Ashikaga Yoshihide, who was a rival to Yoshiaki, in February of the 11th year of Eiroku (1568), when the envoy of the appointment appeared at Genkitsu's residence to request mediation for Yoshiaki's promotion to Jushi-shita.

Yoshiaki, who escaped from Kyoto, initially relied on the father and son, Rokkaku Yoshiyoshi and Rokkaku Yoshiharu of Omi Province, but Yoshiharu secretly colluded with the Miyoshi Trio, so in August he fled to the son-in-law of his sister, Takeda Yoshitsugu in Wakasa Province.

However, the Wakasa Takeda clan did not have enough power to go up to Kyoto due to struggles for succession and power struggles among senior vassals. In September, they fled to the Asakura Yoshikage in Echizen Province and requested assistance in restoring the shogunate.

However, Yoshikage Asakura already held the "Kuragari Gosho" branch of the Ashikaga Shogunate, along with Ashikaga Tsugutomo, and did not have the intention of actively going up to the capital with the newly secularized Ashikaga Yoshiaki, so the journey to the capital did not materialize.

The role of Kanmuriyaku is being served by Asakura Yoshikage (Note that there is no official documentation that Yoshiteru had undergone the coming-of-age ceremony up to this point, making it unusually late for the time).
Eventually, with the mediation of Akechi Mitsuhide, a senior vassal of the Asakura family, he moved to Mino Province to seek the protection of Oda Nobunaga.
In September of the 11th year of Eiroku (1568), he was supported by Oda Nobunaga and went up to Kyoto.
On October 18th, he received the appointment as the 15th shogun from the Imperial Court.
At the same time, he was promoted to Jushi-i-no-jo (Junior Fourth Rank, Upper Grade) and appointed as Sangi (Councilor) and Left Guard General.

Enryaku-ji is a temple located in Sakamoto Honmachi, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture, and encompasses the entire Mount Hiei with an elevation of 848 meters.
From the name of Enryaku-ji Temple, Mount Hiei is often called Hiei-zan or simply Hiei.
It was located north of Heian-kyo (Kyoto) and was also known as Hokurei.
It is the head temple of the Japanese Tendai sect, founded by the monk Saicho in the early Heian period (767-822).
The abbot (kanju) is called the Tendai Zasu and oversees the branch temples.
Since the founding of Kukai, it has been a center of Heian Buddhism alongside Mount Koya's Kongobuji Temple.

In addition to the teachings of the Tendai Lotus Sutra, esoteric Buddhism, Zen (meditation and insight), and chanting of the Buddha's name were also practiced, giving the appearance of a comprehensive Buddhist university. During the Heian period, it gained great power and received the respect of the imperial family and nobility.

In particular, the ritual prayers performed by esoteric Buddhism gathered support from the aristocracy of the Heian period, and the esoteric Buddhism of Enryaku-ji Temple competed for supremacy against the esoteric Buddhism of To-ji Temple (To-mitsu).
"Enryaku-ji" refers to the total of the three towers and sixteen valleys, such as the East Tower, West Tower, and Yokogawa, scattered in the area from the mountaintop of Mt. Hiei to the eastern foot.
In the 7th year of Enryaku (788), Saicho built a small hermitage called Ichijo Shikan-in, which was the beginning.
The temple name "Enryaku-ji," taken from the era name at its founding, was granted in the 14th year of the Kōnin era (824 AD) after the death of Saichō.

Enryaku-ji Temple has produced numerous famous monks, including Ennin and Enchin who laid the foundation of Japanese Tendai Buddhism, Ryōnin the founder of the Yūzū Nembutsu school, Hōnen the founder of Jōdo-shū, Shinran the founder of Jōdo Shinshū, Eihei Dōgen the founder of Sōtō Zen, Eisai the founder of Rinzai Zen, and Nichiren the founder of Nichiren Buddhism. Many founders of new Buddhist sects and famous monks in Japanese Buddhist history have trained on Mount Hiei in their youth, earning it the nickname "the mother mountain of Japanese Buddhism."
Mount Hiei appears in many literary works.

In addition, rigorous ascetic practices such as the "12-year mountain retreat" and the "1,000-day pilgrimage to sacred peaks" have been continued to the present day, and as a representative sacred site of Japanese Buddhism, it is also registered as a World Cultural Heritage site by UNESCO.

Mount Hiei is a mountain whose name is mentioned in the "Kojiki", and it is believed to have been a mountain of mountain worship since ancient times. At the Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine in Sakamoto at the eastern foot of the mountain, the deity Oyamazumi no Kami, the landlord deity of Mount Hiei, is enshrined.

Saicho's secular name was Mitsunobito Hirono, and he was born in the second year of Tenpyo Jingo (766 AD) in Shiga District, Omi Province (Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture). (There is also a theory that he was born in 767 AD).
At the age of 15, in the 11th year of the Hōki era (780), he received ordination (became a monk) under the guidance of the monk Gyōhyō at the Ōmi Kokubunji temple, and took the name Saichō.
At the age of 20, in the 4th year of Enryaku (785), I received ordination at Todai-ji Temple in Nara and became a formal monk.

Young Masumi, for various reasons, did not seek a stable position at a large temple in Nara, but instead secluded himself on Mount Hiei near his hometown, dedicating himself to training and studying scriptures.

Saicho considered the teachings of the Lotus Sutra to be the highest among the numerous scriptures, and he studied the "Three Great Sections of the Lotus Sutra" (Hokke Gengi, Hokke Monju, Makashikan) written by the Chinese Tendai master Zhiyi.
In the 7th year of Enryaku (788), Saicho established a small temple called Ichijo Shikan-in at the current location of the Konpon Chudo, consisting of Yakushi-do, Monju-do, and Kyozo.
This temple is also called Mt. Hiei Temple, and the temple name "Enryaku-ji" with an era name was permitted after the death of Saicho, in the 14th year of the Kōnin era (824 AD).

During the time of Emperor Kanmu, Saicho received the Emperor's and the influential Waki clan's support, and as a result, Mount Hiei Temple gradually prospered as a dojo for national protection guarding the northeast of Kyoto.
In the 21st year of Enryaku (802 AD), Saicho was permitted to travel to Tang as a returning student (short-term overseas training student).
In the 23rd year of Enryaku (804 AD), I crossed over to Tang on a ship as part of a diplomatic mission.
Ennin studied Tendai teachings and Mahayana Bodhisattva precepts under the guidance of Dojo, a direct disciple of the Tendai master Zhiyi, at the sacred site of Mount Hiei.
In addition, at the Longxing Temple in Yuezhou (Shaoxing), they are studying esoteric Buddhism from Shunxiao Ajari and Zen from Shakunen Zenji.
In the Kojiki and Nihon Shoki, it is said to have been created by Izanagi.
It is generally believed that the moon is deified as a god who rules over the night, but there are also alternative theories (see below).
The reading of the name is also Tsukiyomi.
There is a story in the Nihon Shoki about the killing of Yasakatsumi, so although generally considered a male deity, there is no description in the Kojiki or Nihon Shoki that determines gender.

In the myths of other countries, the moon god is often depicted as a goddess, and there are also many goddesses with aggressive personalities in other countries' myths. Therefore, some scholars argue for the goddess theory, stating that the story of the killing of Hosokami by a male god cannot be definitively proven.
Tsukuyomi is considered the god of the moon, but there are various differences in his divinity depending on the literature.

In the Kojiki, it is said that Izanagi was born from his right eye when he escaped from Yomi and performed purification, and Amaterasu, born from his other eye, and Susanoo, born from his nose, together form the three noble children.

On the other hand, in the "Nihon Shoki," there is a story that Amaterasu was born from the left eye, contrary to the "Kojiki," and another story that she emerged from a white bronze mirror held in her right hand, with her dominion not limited to the heavens or the sea.
Tsukuyomi is born in contrast to Amaterasu, who symbolizes the sun, but in the field of comparative mythology, it is pointed out that similar ideas exist in various myths.

For example, in the Chinese legend of Pangu (as recorded in the "Book of History"), it is said that after Pangu died, his left eye became the sun and his right eye became the moon. Similarly, in Greek mythology, the sun god Apollo and the moon goddess Artemis are also depicted as twins.
However, Apollo was originally a different god from the sun god Helios, and it was not until later that the two were identified as the same.

In addition, in the Book of Genesis in the Old Testament, on the fourth day of creation, God created "two great lights" in the sky, namely the sun and the moon, to govern the day and night respectively, and to separate light from darkness. This is the creation of the sun and moon that is described.
The birth of Amaterasu and Tsukuyomi is also considered to follow the pattern of a common worldwide myth of the origin of the sun and moon as a pair.

In Japanese mythology, Tsukuyomi is considered an important god alongside Amaterasu and Susanoo, but he does not appear much in the myths of the Kojiki and Nihon Shoki, and is generally lacking in activity.
It is only briefly mentioned in the Nihon Shoki, Book Five, Section Eleven, that the origin of grains is discussed.
There is a theory that balance is maintained by placing a god who does nothing between the contrasting personalities of Amaterasu and Susanoo.
Similar structures can also be seen in the relationship between Amaterasu and Takamimusubi, as well as between Hoori (Yamato Takeru) and Hoderi (Umisachi).
This is called the hollow structure in Japanese mythology.
Some argue that Susano'o and Susanoo are the same deity due to overlapping domains and episodes.
In the first volume of the Kojiki, it is said that when Izanagi washed his right eye, Amaterasu and Susanoo were born along with him, and they are called the "Three Precious Children."
Tsukuyomi is ordered to "inform the land of night eating," but there is no further activity after this.
There is also a theory that there is a country of Yomimi where the god Izanami resides.

In the fifth section of the Age of the Gods in the Nihon Shoki, it is briefly stated that "a god of the moon, shining brightly after the sun, was born and sent to the heavens to rule alongside the sun." However, in the following first book, there is a different account where Izanagi no Mikoto gave birth to Oho-namuchi no Mikoto while holding a white bronze mirror in his left hand, and gave birth to Tsukiyomi no Mikoto while holding a white bronze mirror in his right hand.

There are several stories about being instructed to rule the heavens alongside Amaterasu-Omikami in the domain of dominion, while there is also a story of being commanded to control the eight hundred layers of the tides of the Cang Hai Yuan (this seems to have come from the idea that the moon controls the tides), and multiple stories of the birth of three gods are parallel.

In the fifth section of the Kojiki, it is said that Amaterasu-Omikami and Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto were both ordered to rule the heavens together. However, later Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto received an order to meet with the god Uke Mochi in the heavens, and descended to meet with Uke Mochi.
In response, the god of food and agriculture spat out rice as an offering, but Tsukiyomi no Mikoto was disgusted and angry, so he killed the god of food and agriculture with a sword.
From the corpse of the food god, cows, horses, silkworms, rice, and other things were born, and this became the origin of grains.
Onmyoji (onmyoji, onyoji) is one of the official positions that belonged to the Onmyoryo of the Nakatsukasasho under the Ritsuryo system in ancient Japan.

It refers to the position of a skilled official (technician) who performs divination, geomancy, and other tasks based on the Yin-Yang Five Elements philosophy, and is later responsible for overseeing divination, sorcery, and all aspects of rituals beyond the original Ritsuryo regulations.

Since the Middle Ages, it has come to refer mainly to non-official individuals who practice divination, sorcery, and rituals privately in various places, and in modern times it is defined as a type of clergy who perform private prayers and divination in the private sector.
It may also be pronounced as "onyoji" without linking sounds.

It is believed that all phenomena are based on the combination of Yin-Yang and Five Elements ideology, which began in ancient China during the Xia and Shang dynasties and was almost completed during the Zhou dynasty. Astronomy, calendars, divination, and timekeeping, which are closely related to this ideology, were transmitted directly from mainland China (Han and Sui dynasties) or through the western regions of the Korean Peninsula (Goguryeo and Baekje) to Japan by the Asuka period in the 5th to 6th centuries, at the latest by the year 512 when scholars of the Five Classics arrived from Baekje during the reign of Emperor Keitai, or by the year 554 when a divination scholar arrived during the reign of Emperor Kinmei.

Although the initial influence of these various studies on politics and culture was minimal, in 602 AD (the 10th year of Empress Suiko), Kanroku, who became a pioneer of Onmyodo in Japan, came from Baekje and began teaching various studies to 34 selected bureaucrats including Prince Shotoku, eventually having a significant impact on our country's politics.

For the first time in Japan, the calendar (Genka calendar) was adopted as the official calendar, and in order to absorb Buddhist teachings, Yin-Yang Five Elements philosophy, and calendar methods, an envoy was sent to Sui, an advanced civilization country, in 607 (15th year of Empress Suiko). The influence of Yin-Yang Five Elements philosophy became prominent in the establishment of Prince Shotoku's Seventeen-Article Constitution and the Twelve-Level Cap and Rank System.

Afterwards, the imperial court continued to send exchange students with the missions to Sui (later Tang) dynasty, and also invited numerous monks or scholars from the western coast of the Korean Peninsula or mainland China to further absorb knowledge.

As the introduction of various studies progresses, it has become important in Japan to consider the movements and positions of the sun, moon, stars, and planets, and to predict the future by judging good and bad luck based on the principles of the Five Elements generating and overcoming each other, in order to obtain guidance for various matters and determine actions. As a strategy to judge good and bad luck and obtain guidelines for actions, the Yin-Yang and Five Elements philosophy has come to be emphasized.

In the 7th century, Emperor Tenmu, who was a master of astrology and had a deep understanding of Yin-Yang and Five Elements philosophy, took a divination rod during the Jinshin War and established the "Onmyoryo" and Japan's first observatory in 676 (the 4th year of Emperor Tenmu's reign).

In the year 685 (13th year of the Tenmu Emperor), the term "Onmyoji" began to be used, and the Yin-Yang Five Elements ideology became even more popular. In the Yoro Ritsuryo of 718, the establishment of the Onmyo-ryo as a bureau within the Nakatsukasa-sho was officially recognized. It was stipulated that the bureau would have permanent officials such as astronomers, Onmyoji, calendar experts, and timekeepers, who, alongside the Kiboku of the Jingikan, were responsible for conducting official divination.

Those responsible for the technology brought from the continent are often scholars and onmyoji who are well-versed in various fields and skilled in reading Chinese texts. They are typically immigrants from mainland China, including those from the former Han, later Han, Sui dynasties that held hegemony over the mainland, as well as Goguryeo and Baekje on the western coast of the Korean Peninsula, and occasionally scholars from Silla, an initial power on the eastern coast of the Korean Peninsula.

In particular, following the defeat in the Battle of Baekgang in 663 AD (2nd year of Tenji), where Japan sent reinforcements to its close ally Baekje, Silla unified the Korean Peninsula after the downfall of the Baekje dynasty. Many scholars from Baekje immigrated as refugees during this period, and a large number of them were appointed to official positions.

The original techniques of the Onmyoryo at the time of its establishment were purely divination, feng shui (similar to what is now called "geomancy"), astronomical observation, astrology, calendar creation, determination of auspicious and inauspicious days, and the management of the calendar. Therefore, they mainly predicted astronomical observations, managed the calendar, and judged the auspiciousness of events based on theoretical analysis according to the principles of Yin and Yang, without performing any religious rituals or sorcery like Shinto priests or monks. However, they played an important role in selecting auspicious days for construction projects at the imperial court and in determining the auspiciousness of locations and directions during events such as the relocation of the capital.
